<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len);

    /* delegate to low-level API */
    return_code = OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return an empty string on failure, just in case */
        host_name[0] = 0;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_NetworkGetHostName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    if (gethostname(host_name, name_len) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * posix does not say that the name is always
         * null terminated, so its worthwhile to ensure it
         */
        host_name[name_len - 1] = 0;
        return_code             = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>

explanation: No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided code. I checked for common compiler extensions such as GCC/Clang builtins or keywords (__attribute__, __asm__, typeof, __builtin_*, statement-expressions ({ ... }), inline assembler, _Pragma or other implementation-defined keywords), none of which appear. The code uses standard C types (size_t, char *) and a typedef of int32_t to int32 (a C99 stdint type, not a compiler extension). The gethostname call is a POSIX library function (an OS API), not a compiler language extension covered by MISRA C: Rule 1.2. The shown macros (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_CHECK_SIZE) expand to other macros (BUGCHECK, ARGCHECK) but their definitions are not provided; the visible expansions do not themselves use language extensions, and there is no evidence in the supplied code that BUGCHECK/ARGCHECK use compiler extensions. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for use of language extensions.
